title: Meet the next-gen Austrian winemakers doing it their way
text:
Max Allen Drinks columnist Oct 4, 2019 — 12.00am Share

‘Right now, in Austria, we are in the middle of a generational transition,” explains Ludwig Hiedler, whose family have been making wine in the Kamptal region, west of Vienna, since 1856. “Younger people like me, who are beginning to take over, we have travelled a lot; we come from completely different backgrounds to our parents.”

Hiedler, 27, was one of three Austrian winemakers in Australia recently for a series of tastings and dinners, representing the new face of the country’s old winemaking tradition.

Theresa Pichler will one day helm a winery that has been in the family since 1731.

Theresa Pichler, 25, said she, too, is aware of the legacy she is inheriting at her family winery in the nearby Wachau region, where steep sloping vineyards rise up from the Danube. “Pichlers started working vineyards here in 1731,” she said. “My father Rudi has really built up the business since he took over in 1997.”

And Martin Nittnaus, 33, talked about coming from a family who can trace their winemaking heritage in the Burgenland village of Gols, near the Hungarian border, back to 1684: “I always fight with my father about winemaking,” he said, smiling. “I want to play the role of the natural wine bad boy.”

Thank god the younger generations get along together and share knowledge and ideas. — Ludwig Hiedler jnr

Even though the three winemakers are clearly good friends and get along well, they each told a different story about how they express the terroir of their vineyard in the glass.

Pichler described how she foot-stomps all the riesling and grüner veltliner grapes that come into the winery, and then leaves the juice in contact with the grape skins for between three and 36 hours before pressing.

Contrary to some of his peers, Martin Nitthaus is "passionate about re-animating the old ways".

“This is very important,” she said. “The skins of the grape receive a lot of ‘information’ as they ripen throughout the growing season, and you need to let the juice macerate in the skins to release that information into the wine. It’s about a gut feeling for each vineyard: you can do longer skin contact for grapes from rocky soils – but if you do it with grapes on sandier soils, the wines are too broad.”
description: They’re young, ambitious and different from their parents’ generation – but they take their legacy, and the weight of expectation, seriously.
